key_insight: A transcriptome-conditioned pipeline converts individual AML patient RNA-seq signatures into personalized de novo small-molecule candidates by combining co-expression-driven target selection with metaheuristic molecular assembly and target-driven filtering. This end-to-end approach links patient biology directly to generative drug design.
problem_solved: Addresses the lack of personalized therapeutic options for molecularly heterogeneous AML patients by automatically translating patient-specific transcriptomic dysregulation into candidate compounds tailored to their disease biology.
method: Extract patient-specific actionable targets from bulk TCGA-LAML RNA-seq via weighted gene co-expression analysis (e.g., WGCNA) and differential expression to prioritize disease modules.
Generate candidate molecules with a metaheuristic assembly engine (optimization-based de novo design guided by transcriptome-derived objectives) to explore chemical space efficiently.
Apply target-driven filtering (in silico affinity prediction / scoring against prioritized targets plus ADMET and drug-likeness filters) to rank personalized leads.
impact: Demonstrates how integrating omics-driven target selection with optimization-based generative chemistry can produce personalized drug hypotheses — a useful blueprint for ML practitioners building clinically oriented molecule design pipelines and evaluation benchmarks.
visual_elements: Workflow diagram: patient RNA-seq -> target prioritization -> generative assembly -> target-driven filtering -> ranked personalized leads

paper_title: Transcriptome-Conditioned Personalized De Novo Drug Generation for AML Using Metaheuristic Assembly and Target-Driven Filtering
paper_authors: Abdullah G. Elafifi, Basma Mamdouh, Mariam Hanafy, Muhammed Alaa Eldin, Yosef Khaled
